source.718fa8ce:
# Create a html document containing the output
from yattag import Doc

def render_text(tag, text, raw_text):
    for i, snippet in enumerate(raw_text.split("#$#")):
        class_name = "marked" if i % 2 != 0 else ""
        with tag('span', klass=class_name):
            text(snippet)

def render_queries(tag, text, queries):
    for qri, query in enumerate(queries):
        with tag('div', klass="query text"):
            with tag('h4'):
                text(query["text"])
        with tag('div', klass="query comment"):
            with tag('p'):
                text(query["comment"])
        with tag('div', klass="query snippets", style="background-color: #E8E9EB;color:#313638;"):
            for sni, snippet in enumerate(query["snippets"]):
                with tag('a', href=snippet["url"], style="margin-bottom:1em;text-decoration:none;"):
                    text(snippet["title"])
                with tag('p', klass="snippet"):
                    render_text(tag, text, snippet["text"])

def render_questions(tag, text, questions):
    for qi, question in enumerate(questions):
        with tag('div', klass="question entry"):
            with tag('div', klass="question text collapsible"):
                with tag('h3'):
                    text(question["text"])
            with tag('div', klass="queries group"):
                render_queries(tag, text, question["queries"])

def render_tasks(tag, text, tasks):
    for ti, task in enumerate(tasks):
        with tag('div', klass="task entry"):
            with tag('div', klass="task text collapsible"):
                with tag('h2'):
                    text(task["text"])
            with tag('div', klass="questions group"):
                render_questions(tag, text, task["questions"])
source.bb675816:
## Data processing

Work was done by [SpotlightData](https://www.spotlightdata.co.uk/)

### Introduction

All of the data was uploaded to a postgres database and then processed via Nanowire pipeline. Postgres provides us with a fast, full text search on vectorised text of the published papers. 

Using Nanowire, the following data was extracted:

* keywords
* bigrams
* trigrams
* entities
* biomedical entities (craft, jba, bc5cdr, bio13cg)

### Reducing the data set

At the time of processing, the data set was over 29 000 documents, with most papers not being relevant for our search needs. In order to filter out the papers we were interested in, we used postgres text search to only return documents, which contained the terms `'coronavirus | COVID:* | SARS-CoV:*'`.

This reduces the data we need to process down to 16588 papers, but still includes ones, that might only mention the virus once in the whole document, which isn’t very relevant to us. 

Now, that we have less documents, we can run `ts_stats` to get the occurrences of each word per document. As we only care about the terms we search for, we filter down the words further, by doing:

`to_tsvector(sq.word) @@ (to_tsquery('coronavirus') || to_tsquery('COVID:*') || to_tsquery('SARS-CoV:*'))`

At this point we have a document_uuid and word counts for the terms we searched. The next step is to only show documents, which mention any of the terms more than 20 times.

`having sum(nentry) > 20`

This reduces the number of documents down to 1500. Which means, we can now export the graph way easier.


## Data available

### Neo4j graph data
We created a neo4j graph, which links papers with authors as well as the mentioned extract from the data keywords, bigrams, entities, ...etc.

It can be found on our [dropbox](https://www.dropbox.com/sh/0oxrw7yz7y2x41a/AAAa5t6sIsdj5BuCbl4DqajCa?dl=0)

### Postgres data dump
All of the processed data and our filtered down documents can be found in the file created by `pg_dump`on our [dropbox](https://www.dropbox.com/sh/w311zu6yc0fxfcj/AAASFnx6ENrjcEkvuqCYx9UPa?dl=0). Open the README.md for instructions on importing the data

### Public postgres instance
Data is also available via a hosted postgres instance:

```
(user = 'data_access',
                              password = 'H5yfSApxS5bk6f',
                              host = 'spotlightdata-covid-do-user-1518235-0.a.db.ondigitalocean.com',
                              port = '25060',
                              database = 'covid')
> ```
